Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Antarctic Paleobotany: Permian Floral Characteristics in a Sedimentary Setting
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will involve examination of Glossopteridales, fossil plants from Upper Permian deposits, in samples from the central Transantarctic Mountains and Southern Victoria Land, Antarctica. The glossopterids are an important fossil group because they are possible ancestors to the flowering plants. Permian sedimentary rocks (295-270 Ma before present) are important because they record a time of rapid biotic change, as the Late Paleozoic Age ended and the Mesozoic greenhouse environment began. The proposed research will rely entirely on specimens collected during recent field excursions to the central Transantarctic Mountains (CTM; 2010?2011) and southern Victoria Land (SVL; 2012?2013). Only a few of the specimens have been studied, but already have yielded anatomically well-preserved glossopterids with a complete pollen cone, which has never been found before. Additionally, several seed-bearing structures, which have never before been observed in Antarctica, have been found in both CTM and SVL. The project will allow comparison of whole-plant fossil glossopterids from the CTM with other paleo-latitudes, and will document the floral diversity within and between two depositional basins (CTM & SVL) during a time of global change, with the overall goal of linking environmental changes with fossil morphology.

Broader impacts:
The Broader Impacts of this project will include mentoring undergraduates in research projects, at an institution with a substantial minority enrollment. Public outreach will focus on involving middle/high school students through the ?Expanding Your Horizons? programs in Kansas and Missouri, as well as interactive presentations at schools in the Kansas City Area. The lead PI is an early-career scientist at an institution that serves minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was to establish an undergraduate research program in Antarctic fossil plants at Park University in the Kansas City area. At the beginning there was no space or equipment to carry out 21st century level research as the available equipment dated to classroom grade materials from the 1980s. With funds from this grant digital microscopes as well as supporting software were purchased to allow students across both biological and geological disciplines to create high resolution images for analysis of a publishable grade. Chemicals and safety equipment were also purchased so undergraduates could conduct experiments following proper safety protocols for hazardous chemicals.

Students carried out all aspects of scientific research from finding a question to answer up to writing a scientific paper for publication. Most students are not exposed to this process until they start graduate school and being able to perform at this level at a small private undergraduate University is rare. Students presented their research to the community at national conferences giving them experience on how to present their research in a professional setting rather than an informal classroom setting helping them enhance and refine their communication skills. Student topics are expanding the scope of Antarctic fossil plants. Traditionally describing fossil plants has been the focus of research, but now enough information is known at the plants so students funded through this grant worked on interactions between plants and animals (herbivory) and the life history (how plants changed through a year) of plants.

Promoting Antarctic science as well as science education was an important component of this project. Not only were discussions and presentations conducted at the undergraduate level, but also at the community level. Hands-on activity with K–12 students and parents introduced them to fossil plants (there’s more than just dinosaurs) and let them actually use a technique to look at the cells in a plant fossil. They get to walk away with knowing about Antarctica, fossil plants, and their on slice of a fossil (appropriately chosen specimens dedicated to teaching with no research value). Two to three public activities were held each year of the grant.
